topics.body:
"@Gizoid101":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/558f675c6368727f63000395#post_558f675c6368727f63000395
[bq="Gizoid101"]"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/558f64b96368724e600001a5#post_558f64b96368724e600001a5
[bq="trashboat"]What's happening?[/bq]
@A LOT OF PEOPLE IS TALKING SMART ABOUT TECNOLOGY@[/bq]
Tl:dr;
Quantum processors use subatomic particles to crunch lots of numbers.
Computer chips that emulate how brain cells work crunch "logic" better as in they're better at "understanding" how the logic of a formula works; would help a fuck ton with finding solutions to bugs in programming.
New chips in development that will be here soon use light instead of electricity and are really fast.
"@liamwhite1":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/558f681b6368727f5200058a#post_558f681b6368727f5200058a
[bq="liamwhite1"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/558f67956368727f45000544#post_558f67956368727f45000544
Dude, they're going to be building regular computers with InGaAs chips in less than 10 years. Intel, tick-tock.[/bq]
Fuck yeah!

OH!  I almost forgot something.  Two other things that are being worked on is they can now store data fourth dimensionally.  For years they've been working on say holodiscs, but that didn't pan out but a holo-hard drive would be amazing.  The other thing is a while back they managed to store data atomically on a disc; a square centimeter is able to store a TB.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/558f686e636872233500022a#post_558f686e636872233500022a
One of the interesting things that the small scale that InGaAs chips can operate in is that they are more and more affected by quantum tunneling - if this could be turned advantageously, then that might mean tremendous speedups for us.
